citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
One young male cavy has injuries from another cavy that the facility has not addressed. The cavy has an area of missing
fur that covers the majority of the middle back and extends towards the rear. In this section, the cavy has numerous open
wounds that have a wet, oozy appearance as well as some scabbed and crusted spots. The cavy’s tail appears crusted
with areas of pink showing through. When asked about the animal’s injuries, the facility representative stated that they
had noticed some changes in the fur along the back but that they had not noticed the wounds to the back and tail.
Inadequate daily observations can lead to the prolonged suffering of animals when injuries or changes in their health or
behavior are not noticed in a timely manner. The facility must ensure that all animals are observed daily to assess their
health and well-being and then ensure a mechanism of direct and frequent communication with the attending veterinarian.
The facility must obtain veterinary care for the injured cavy.
To be corrected by close of business on March 13, 2025, or prior to the next licensing inspection, whichever comes first.

The facility is not ensuring that animals housed together are compatible. While looking at the enclosure housing five
cavies, the APHIS inspector observed one cavy chasing and biting another cavy. This behavior continued the entire time
the inspector was at the enclosure. The cavy being chased is missing fur along its back and has broken skin in multiple
areas. When asked, the facility representative stated that they had noticed the older adult male starting to chase and bite
the younger male but that they had not separated them yet.
Housing incompatible animals together in the same primary enclosure can lead to stress, injury, and even death. Animals
housed in the same primary enclosure must be compatible. The facility must separate these two cavies.
To be corrected by close of business on March 13, 2025, or prior to the next licensing inspection, whichever comes first.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by May 11, 2025, or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
One young male cavy has injuries from another cavy that the facility has not addressed. The cavy has an area of missing 
fur that covers the majority of the middle back and extends towards the rear. In this section, the cavy has numerous open 
wounds that have a wet, oozy appearance as well as some scabbed and crusted spots. The cavy’s tail appears crusted 
with areas of pink showing through. When asked about the animal’s injuries, the facility representative stated that they 
had noticed some changes in the fur along the back but that they had not noticed the wounds to the back and tail.  
 
Inadequate daily observations can lead to the prolonged suffering of animals when injuries or changes in their health or 
behavior are not noticed in a timely manner. The facility must ensure that all animals are observed daily to assess their 
health and well-being and then ensure a mechanism of direct and frequent communication with the attending veterinarian. 
The facility must obtain veterinary care for the injured cavy. 
 
To be corrected by close of business on March 13, 2025, or prior to the next licensing inspection, whichever comes first. 
3.133  Direct
   
Separation. 
The facility is not ensuring that animals housed together are compatible. While looking at the enclosure housing five 
cavies, the APHIS inspector observed one cavy chasing and biting another cavy. This behavior continued the entire time 
the inspector was at the enclosure. The cavy being chased is missing fur along its back and has broken skin in multiple 
areas. When asked, the facility representative stated that they had noticed the older adult male starting to chase and bite 
the younger male but that they had not separated them yet. 
 
Housing incompatible animals together in the same primary enclosure can lead to stress, injury, and even death. Animals 
housed in the same primary enclosure must be compatible. The facility must separate these two cavies. 
 
To be corrected by close of business on March 13, 2025, or prior to the next licensing inspection, whichever comes first.

This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by May 11, 2025, or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
 n

species.scientific: Ara, Anodorhynchus, Primolius, Diopsittaca spp hybrid
